column47: his friend might shoot guns at the wall. So John ALWAYS had a near-guarantee of eventually having anÂ â€˜episodeâ€™ The Fall was traumatizing

column49: forcing himself to trust her at Sherlockâ€™s reassurances (sherlock telling him that heâ€™s SAFE with her
column51: shes a comrade-in-arms) and then to have her bleed out? INCREDIBLY traumatic. I know people dont like the phraseÂ â€˜triggerâ€™ but thats the REAL WORD and it doesnt always meanÂ â€˜break into sobsâ€™ and it doesnt always meanÂ â€˜right nowâ€™. So John
column54: had another comrade-in-arms die on him
column55: Sherlock didnt come for him (he said he thought sherlock would but hadnt been interested)
column56: John is having auditory and visual hallucinations. He knows he cant trust what heâ€™s seeing or doing
column58: sends Rosie away to somewhere SAFE because he doesnâ€™t know what he will (or wont) do. Tries to go to therapy
column59: only for the world to crash in on him and tell him he needs to be responsible

column62: John trusts him anyways.Â  Smith is taunting him
column64: threatening women and children and doctors and nurses
column67: plays with the dead body of a woman in front of him
column68: suddenly Sherlock appears to snap and go into his own episode
column70: no longer trustworthy John tries to disarm him
column73: locks into his feelings of not being safe
column77: thinking ever since ghost-mary arrived that hes Not Safe And goes too far and EPISODE I know yall think that it wasÂ â€˜a beatingâ€™ andÂ â€˜abusiveâ€™ but from what iâ€™ve seen (and ive seen a LOT) ptsd vets can do some wild shit that only barely makes sense to them
column78: even afterwards. Thats usually the sort of thing that makes them admit they need help and go to get medication and finally submit themselves to therapy
column79: the therapy John has needed for YEARS. And they almost ALWAYS improve with it
column81: even if thye never get back toÂ â€˜normalâ€™ JOhn was left completely adrift with no support system
column82: and honestly beating up a friend that was ALSO having a breakdown while brandishing a knife???? that shit happens so often in active warzones that John probably wouldnt even go off-duty for it.Â  Tensions are high and John has been taught to treat London as a war zone. Then afterwards he doesnt beg forgiveness
column83: because he doesnt think he deserves it
column84: doesnt say he wont ever do it again because he didnt intend to do it in the first place. He just tries to push himself away from sherlock (just like rosie
column85: who he also doesnt feel safe with) and get help. I think when sherlock saidÂ â€˜maybe we are humanâ€“ even youâ€™ i think he meant that JOhn had done well trying to hold himself together without any support for so long
column86: and that cracks were inevitable. It is
column88: impossible for John to not have ptsd after all that he went through
column89: and the fact that he held together this long is AMAZING and i do NOT judge him for losing control. His control is ALWAYS on

column10: and even the Garridebs) and in the fallout after. I wanted Mycroft. I wanted bonding with Rosie (not only with Sherlock
column11: but also with John). I wanted Sherlock and John to have their happy ending. Most of all
column18: and I wanted our beloved characters to finally open up and be honest with one another. I got it all
column19: in spades.Â  I really REALLY cannot say enough how much I love what DW has done in this story to tie together so many of the loose ends we were left with. Itâ€™s tagged a fix-it and it does
column21: TFP is real and this is what happened during and after. Itâ€™s a beautifully written and compelling story that runs an emotional gamut from anxiety and unease and fear to healing and warmth and brotherhood and so much love. We come full circle with Sherlock as he works to make Baker Street truly home. This has left me with a much more satisfying lens through which to view TFP.Â  I am beyond thrilled and grateful for your time and talent and for this most stunning story
column23: so indescribably happy that youâ€™re pleased with the final result. I had a lot of thoughts and feelings about S4 as a whole
column24: but they were scattered and lacked focus. Being able to talk out what we both did and didnâ€™t like (as well your wishlist of things you wanted to see!) gave me a target to focus in on. It was a joy to work on this story for you. Thank you again so much for bidding on me! <3 I just finished this tonight and it is an earth-movingly wonderful read. Your conversation must have been one hell of a talk because this was catharsis that was needed from way back. Iâ€™m really in awe and I canâ€™t thank you both enough for sharing with the world. Wonderful fic. Iâ€™m still finding the words and failing." False link

column1: avawatson 144286907559 "2016-05-13 06:29:27 GMT" https://avawatson.tumblr.com/post/144286907559/martin-freeman-to-star-in-zombie-thriller-cargo "free-martinis:     The Hobbit star to topline zombie thriller from The Babadook producer; Bankside launches sales. The Hobbit star Martin Freeman is attached to star in zombie pandemic thriller Cargo from producer Kristina Ceyton (The Babadook). column2: which had success at the local box office with The Babadook. Umbrella Entertainment will release in Australia/New Zealand. The feature is based on Yolanda Ramke and Ben Howlingâ€™s short of the same name
column3: which clocked more than 10 million views on YouTube. Howling will direct with fellow first-time feature directorÂ Ramke
column4: who has also written the script. Freeman
column5: who stars alongside Benedict Cumberbatch in hit BBC series Sherlock
column6: will play a father who
column7: stranded in rural Australia in the aftermath of a violent pandemic and
column9: desperately seeks a new home for his infant child and a means to protect her from his own changing nature. Sam Jennings of Australiaâ€™s Causeway Films produces with Ceyton alongside Russell Ackerman and John Schoenfelder of LA-based Addictive Pictures. The film is set to shoot in Australia in fall 2016. Financiers include Screen Australia
column10: South Australian Film Commission and Head Gear Films.Â CAA and BanksideÂ co-represent North American rights. Banksideâ€™s head of sales and marketing
column12: said: â€œWe are delighted to be working with the producers of The Babadook on Cargo. These filmmakers have a distinctive and elegant approach to the genre that we are certain will excite distributors and audiences worldwide.â€ Ceyton added: â€œMartin Freeman is a singular talent who will add such depth and emotional sophistication to the role
column13: and we know will make this story come alive in an unexpected and deeply moving way. We look forward to working with our partners Addictive Pictures and Bankside Films on this very special project.â€ " False link

column1: avawatson 138792750598 "2016-02-06 15:00:38 GMT" https://avawatson.tumblr.com/post/138792750598/special-issue-cfp-sherlock-holmes-fandom "dragonsbain:Please pass this around. From the site:Sherlock Holmes has attracted devoted fans almost since the date of first publication in 1887. The oldest still-existing Sherlockian society
column2: the Baker Street Irregulars
column3: was founded in 1934
column4: while the Sherlock Holmes Society of London dates from 1951. More recent additions to the ever-growing network of organized Sherlock Holmes literary societies include the formerly all-female Adventuresses of Sherlock Holmes
column5: and fan groups in the media fandom model have arisen
column6: such as the Baker Street Babes and other online communities. This special issue seeks to engage both academics and fans in writing about the older
column7: long established Sherlockian fandom. We welcome papers that address all fandoms of Sherlock Holmes and its adaptations
column8: particularly those that trace the connections and similarities/differences among and between older and newer fandoms.We welcome submissions dealing with
column10: the following topics:* Questions of nomenclature
column15: and sexuality.* The role of Sherlockian fandom and the Great Game in fandom history.* Academic histories of Sherlockian fandom
column16: both organized and informal.* Connections between new adaptation-based fandoms and the older fandom.* Fan productions
column20: and Sherlockian writings on the Canon.* Influence of intellectual property law and norms on adaptations and fan productions.* Sherlockian publishing
column24: BSI Press or Wessex Press.* Community
column26: Sherlockians on the Internet or Sherlockian â€œreal worldâ€ gatherings.* Specific national fandoms
column28: Japanese or Chinese Sherlock Holmes reception.Submission guidelinesTransformative Works and Cultures (TWC
column29: http://journal.transformativeworks.org/) is an international peer-reviewed online Gold Open Access publication of the nonprofit Organization for Transformative Works copyrighted under a Creative Commons License. TWC aims to provide a publishing outlet that welcomes fan-related topics and to promote dialogue between the academic community and the fan community. TWC accommodates academic articles of varying scope as well as other forms that embrace the technical possibilities of the Web and test the limits of the genre of academic writing.Theory: Conceptual essays. Peer review
column32: 000 words.Praxis: Case study essays. Peer review
column38: 500 words.Please visit TWCâ€™s Web site (http://journal.transformativeworks.org/) for complete submission guidelines
column39: or e-mail the TWC Editor (editor AT transformativeworks.org).Contactâ€”Contact guest editors Betsy Rosenblatt and Roberta Pearson with any questions or inquiries at twcsherlock AT gmail.com.Due dateâ€”March 1
column41: for estimated March 2017 publication." False link
